AP_Style_Scoring_Table.Scoring_Criteria:
- Number writing rules:
  1-9 should be written in words; 10 and above should use Arabic numerals.
  Always use Arabic numerals for ages, amounts, percentages, dates, and times.
- Ordinal numbers:
  Do not use 'st', 'nd', 'rd', or 'th'.
- Plural forms:
  Do not add an apostrophe to plural numbers (e.g., '7s').
AP_Style_Scoring_Table.Incorrect_Examples:
- 'I have 7 apples.'
- 'The event is on the 3rd day.'
- 'She is twenty-five years old.'
- 'All 7’s rolled.'
AP_Style_Scoring_Table.Correct_Examples:
- 'I have seven apples.'
- 'The event is on the third day.'
- 'She is 25 years old.'
- 'All 7s rolled.'

AP_Style_Scoring_Table.Scoring_Criteria:
- Quotation marks:
  Periods and commas always go inside quotation marks.
- Oxford comma:
  Avoid using the Oxford comma in lists.
- Space rules:
  Use only one space after a period.
- Colons:
  Capitalize the first letter after a colon only if it starts a complete sentence or is a proper noun.
AP_Style_Scoring_Table.Incorrect_Examples:
- He said, 'Let’s go'.
- Red, white, and blue.
- This is a sentence.  Another one follows.
- 'The following: rules.'
AP_Style_Scoring_Table.Correct_Examples:
- He said, 'Let’s go.'
- Red, white and blue.
- This is a sentence. Another one follows.
- 'The following: Rules.'

AP_Style_Scoring_Table.Scoring_Criteria:
- Date rules:
  Do not use ordinal indicators like '1st'.
  Abbreviate months as Jan., Feb., Aug., Sept., Oct., Nov., Dec.
- Time rules:
  Use a.m./p.m. format and omit ':00' for whole hours.
  Write 'midnight' and 'noon' instead of '12 a.m.' or '12 p.m.'
AP_Style_Scoring_Table.Incorrect_Examples:
- 'The event is on July 3rd.'
- 'It starts at 8:00 p.m.'
- 'Meet me at 12 p.m.'
AP_Style_Scoring_Table.Correct_Examples:
- 'The event is on July 3.'
- 'It starts at 8 p.m.'
- 'Meet me at noon.'

AP_Style_Scoring_Table.Scoring_Criteria:
- Street address rules:
  Abbreviate 'Ave.', 'Blvd.', 'St.' but spell out 'Road'.
- State name rules:
  Abbreviate state names after city names (except Alaska, Hawaii, Idaho, etc.).
- Direction rules:
  Use lowercase for directions like 'north' and 'south'.
AP_Style_Scoring_Table.Incorrect_Examples:
- '1600 Pennsylvania Avenue'
- 'Nashville, Tennessee'
- 'We went to the East last year.'
AP_Style_Scoring_Table.Correct_Examples:
- '1600 Pennsylvania Ave.'
- 'Nashville, Tenn.'
- 'We went east last year.'

AP_Style_Scoring_Table.Scoring_Criteria:
- Title rules:
  Capitalize formal titles before a person's name; use lowercase after the name or when used alone.
  Avoid courtesy titles like Mr., Mrs., Ms.
- Gender-neutral language:
  Use gender-neutral terms (e.g., 'police officer' instead of 'policeman').
AP_Style_Scoring_Table.Incorrect_Examples:
- 'President Joe Biden visited.'
- 'Joe Biden, President, spoke.'
- 'The policeman arrived.'
AP_Style_Scoring_Table.Correct_Examples:
- 'President Joe Biden visited.'
- 'Joe Biden, the president, spoke.'
- 'The police officer arrived.'

AP_Style_Scoring_Table.Scoring_Criteria:
- Reference rules:
  Add quotation marks around titles of articles, books, movies, songs, etc.
  Do not use quotation marks for newspaper or magazine names; capitalize them.
  Use website titles instead of URLs.
- Reference format:
  Provide full information on first mention; simplify subsequent mentions.
AP_Style_Scoring_Table.Incorrect_Examples:
- 'I read the New York Times today.'
- 'Check out www.google.com.'
- 'According to the study.'
AP_Style_Scoring_Table.Correct_Examples:
- 'I read The New York Times today.'
- 'Check out Google.'
- 'According to the study by Smith et al.'

AP_Style_Scoring_Table.Scoring_Criteria:
- Proper nouns:
  Capitalize specific names (e.g., places, institutions).
- Seasons and directions:
  Only capitalize seasons/directions in specific cases (e.g., 'Winter Olympics').
- Abbreviations:
  Follow capitalization rules for abbreviations.
AP_Style_Scoring_Table.Incorrect_Examples:
- 'The River flows north.'
- 'We went to the East last year.'
- 'The study was conducted in the Summer.'
AP_Style_Scoring_Table.Correct_Examples:
- 'The river flows north.'
- 'We went east last year.'
- 'The study was conducted in the summer.'

AP_Style_Scoring_Table.Scoring_Criteria:
- Technical terms:
  Spell technical terms correctly (e.g., 'email', 'smartphone').
  Capitalize brand names like 'iPhone'.
  Write 'website' as one word and 'web page' as two words.
- Spelling:
  Ensure accurate spelling of technical terms.
AP_Style_Scoring_Table.Incorrect_Examples:
- 'I sent an E-mail.'
- 'Check out my new Iphone.'
- 'Visit our Webpage.'
AP_Style_Scoring_Table.Correct_Examples:
- 'I sent an email.'
- 'Check out my new iPhone.'
- 'Visit our web page.'

AP_Style_Scoring_Table.Scoring_Criteria:
- Brevity:
  Avoid long or complex sentences.
- Readability:
  Use simple language suitable for general audiences.
- Consistency:
  Maintain consistent style throughout the text.
AP_Style_Scoring_Table.Incorrect_Examples:
- 'The aforementioned individual arrived at the location.'
- 'This is a highly technical subject matter.'
AP_Style_Scoring_Table.Correct_Examples:
- 'The person arrived at the site.'
- 'This is a technical topic.'

AP_Style_Scoring_Table.Scoring_Criteria:
- Consistency:
  Maintain consistent style for numbers, punctuation, capitalization, etc.
- Style:
  Avoid mixing styles (e.g., APA, Chicago).
- Structure:
  Ensure logical flow and clear paragraph transitions.
AP_Style_Scoring_Table.Incorrect_Examples:
- Mixed number formats (e.g., 'seven' and '8')
- Inconsistent punctuation (e.g., 'quote.' vs. 'quote.')
- Large jumps between paragraphs.
AP_Style_Scoring_Table.Correct_Examples:
- Unified number formats.
- Consistent punctuation.
- Smooth paragraph transitions.
